thread.section_title: Sports - Crain's New York Business News Feed
thread.title: Mayor vs. Moskowitz: How their mutual dislike benefits both
thread.title_full: Mayor vs. Moskowitz: How their mutual dislike benefits both

author: Andrew J. Hawkins and Amanda Fung
title: Mayor vs. Moskowitz: How their mutual dislike benefits both
text:
Photo: Associated Press/Getty Images Mayor Bill de Blasio and Eva Moskowitz 
Success Academy Charter Schools founder Eva Moskowitz and Mayor Bill de Blasio will never be friends. But her declaration that she won't seek his job might make it easier for them to coexist—which would help her business. And perhaps his mayoralty, too.At a City Hall press conference, Moskowitz cited her focus on her education empire, which she hopes to grow to 100 schools from 34 today, as a reason not to run for mayor. She earns more than $475,000 a year as CEO.Success Academy's future growth depends on getting space within traditional public schools and donations from its base of wealthy supporters. Both could have been jeopardized by a campaign."Not running for mayor is good for business," said Kenneth Sherrill, professor of political science at Hunter College.Education-reform donors, especially on Wall Street, are loath to wade into political scraps, Sherrill noted. Donations to Success Academy would have been seen as investments in de Blasio's replacement.Moskowitz and de Blasio dislike each other, and her decision won't completely thaw their icy relationship. But Moskowitz's charter-school network is already controversial, and running for mayor would have complicated its dealings with the city."This parlor game has reached the point where it may have negative side effects" for Moskowitz's business, one charter-school supporter said, adding that if the de Blasio administration were intent on acting "irrationally" toward her, she was smart to remove her political ambitions from the equation. Fantasy sports probe 
Employees at fantasy sports sites FanDuel and DraftKings are being investigated for profiting from placing bets using internal company data. State Attorney General Eric Schneiderman has requested data from both sites. Reacting to the allegations, the companies banned employees from participating in the daily contests. Blackstone's murky fees 
The private-equity giant agreed to pay $39 million to settle a Securities and Exchange Commission charge concerning a type of upfront fee that it collects from companies it owns. It was the first time in the firm's 30-year history that it was called out by the SEC for violating securities law. Brooklyn explosion not caused by gas 
Officials eliminated natural gas as the cause of a building explosion in Borough Park, Brooklyn, that killed two and injured 10 people earlier this month. Authorities are now investigating whether an accelerant or some type of fuel triggered the blast. Gas leaks were the cause of building explosions in the East Village earlier this year and in East Harlem in 2014. 3-D printer maker shrinks 
MakerBot is laying off 20% of its staff--the second time this year it has done so. Six months ago, the 3-D printer manufacturer cut 100 staffers and closed three retail stores. Although MakerBot will maintain its 17,000-square-foot Industry City factory , it will move research and development to its headquarters in downtown Brooklyn. MakerBot was a pioneer of low-cost 3-D printing but has struggled in recent years. Ann Inc. gets new leader Datapoint Uber will lease 20,000 square feet in the same Long Island City building where the Taxi and Limousine Commission will be moving next month. 
Kay Krill was replaced as president and CEO of Ann Inc. by the company's deputy. Gary Muto will take over the Manhattan-based parent of clothing and accessory brands Loft and Ann Taylor. Krill, who led Ann since 2005, will join the board of Ann's parent, Ascena Retail Group. Dewey execs await final verdict 
Three senior executives at now-defunct law firm Dewey & LeBouef are off the hook on some charges. A jury found them not guilty of falsifying business documents, but the panel had not yet reached a verdict on fraud, larceny and conspiracy charges as of press time. They could face up to 25 years in prison if found guilty on those charges. Carnegie Hall interim chair 
Philanthropist Mercedes Bass will temporarily replace billionaire Ronald Perelman as chair of Carnegie Hall. Perelman stepped down after raising concerns about the venue's finances and what he described as a lack of transparency. Mayor to retailers: Shut the door 
When the warm weather returns next year, retailers will have to comply with a new law signed by Mayor Bill de Blasio last week requiring shops and restaurants to keep doors and windows closed while air conditioners are operating. A 2008 law applied only to stores 4,000 square feet or larger. Eateries with sidewalk cafés are exempt. The law goes into effect in 2016 and imposes a $250 fine for the first offense and as much as $1,000 for repeat violations. A version of this article appears in the October 12, 2015, print issue of Crain's New York Business.
